data.title: DisplayOrientation revision
data.body:
We are working on unifying WP8 with the other platforms of MonoGame. The straightforward solution is to have a device orientation and a desired orientation and if they don't match, we apply a rotation to our game. This is working fine, but we have noticed that the DisplayOrientation is implemented in a confusing and hard to use way.

Let's take a look at the MonoGame code of DisplayOrientation:

``` C#
    [Flags]
    public enum DisplayOrientation
    {
        /// <summary>
        /// In Xna, this value is Default = 0. The effect of setting
        /// GraphicsDeviceManager.SupportedOrientations = Default is the same as setting
        /// GraphicsDeviceManager.SupportedOrientations = LandscapeLeft | LandscapeRight.
        /// </summary>
        Default = 1,
        LandscapeLeft = 2,
        LandscapeRight = 4,
        Portrait = 8,
        // iPhone specific Orientations
        FaceDown = 16,
        FaceUp = 32,
        // Android can also use this orientation
        PortraitUpsideDown = 64,
        Unknown = 128,
    }
```

The same in XNA (Click go to definition):

``` C#
    [Flags]
    public enum DisplayOrientation
    {
        Default = 0,
        LandscapeLeft = 1,
        LandscapeRight = 2,
        Portrait = 4
    }
```

I have spent plenty of time working with iOS orientations (implementing iOS 6 orientation model for example). FaceDown and FaceUp are never used. As for PortraitUpsideDown I would recommend renaming it to PortraitDown (see http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-US/library/windowsphone/develop/microsoft.phone.controls.pageorientation%28v=vs.105%29.aspx).
## My recommendation for DisplayOrientation

``` C#
    [Flags]
    public enum DisplayOrientation
    {
        Default = 0,
        LandscapeLeft = 1,
        LandscapeRight = 2,
        Portrait = 4,
        PortraitDown = 8,
        Unknown = 16
    }
```

Default can mean LandscapeLeft | LandscapeRight or Portrait depending on the requested resolution (the comment in MonoGame is wrong), so it should stay 0.

What do you guys think? Any input is welcome.

Further reading:
http://blogs.msdn.com/b/shawnhar/archive/2010/07/12/orientation-and-rotation-on-windows-phone.aspx

Orientations need some additional work on WP8, as it isn't implemented at the moment.
## My recommendation for WP8

GraphicsDevice.PresentationParameters.DisplayOrientation should be set to Portrait, as the swap chain is always in portrait.

The GamePage.xaml should have all orientations enabled (Portrait+LandscapeLeft+LandscapeRight). The XAML should notify the WPGameWindow every time the device orientation changes (display orientation remains portrait!). If the new orientation is part of SupportedOrientations, we set the CurrentOrientation to our new rotation and notify the game if needed.

This way, the game will see what orientation it should be in and what orientation the GraphicsDevice has.

data.title: Future of starter-kits, samples, tests and third-party libs submodules?
data.body:
All of those project assets are split around different user repo's and most of them aren't maintained i guess.  (ie windows samples doesn't compile at all).

Will they continue living as orphan submodules or will we ever get them merged to main project so - they can get more attention & get fixed.

I remember @migueldeicaza also mentioning on IRC that sample projects needed to be fixed before the 3.0 stable fix which quite seems reasonable.

data.title: [WP8] Handling orientation
data.body:
We are working on unifying WP8 with the other platforms of MonoGame. The straightforward solution is to have a device orientation and a desired orientation and if they don't match, we apply a rotation to our game. This is working fine (and the only big bug left in WP8 is RenderTarget), but orientations need some additional work on WP8, as they are currently "unset".
## My recommendation

GraphicsDevice.PresentationParameters.DisplayOrientation should be set to Portrait, as the swap chain is always in portrait.

The GamePage.xaml should have all orientations enabled (Portrait+LandscapeLeft+LandscapeRight). The XAML should notify the WPGameWindow every time the device orientation changes (display orientation remains portrait!). If the new orientation is part of SupportedOrientations, we set the CurrentOrientation to our new rotation and notify the game if needed.

This way, the game will see what orientation it should be in and what orientation the GraphicsDevice has.

If you agree on this with me, I will submit a PR.

data.title: DisplayOrientation needs revision
data.body:
We are working on unifying WP8 with the other platforms of MonoGame. The straightforward solution is to have a device orientation and a desired orientation and if they don't match, we apply a rotation to our game. This is working fine (and the only big bug left in WP8 is RenderTarget), but we have noticed that the DisplayOrientation is implemented in a confusing and hard to use way.

Let's take a look at the MonoGame code of DisplayOrientation:

``` C#
    [Flags]
    public enum DisplayOrientation
    {
        /// <summary>
        /// In Xna, this value is Default = 0. The effect of setting
        /// GraphicsDeviceManager.SupportedOrientations = Default is the same as setting
        /// GraphicsDeviceManager.SupportedOrientations = LandscapeLeft | LandscapeRight.
        /// </summary>
        Default = 1,
        LandscapeLeft = 2,
        LandscapeRight = 4,
        Portrait = 8,
        // iPhone specific Orientations
        FaceDown = 16,
        FaceUp = 32,
        // Android can also use this orientation
        PortraitUpsideDown = 64,
        Unknown = 128,
    }
```

The same in XNA (Click go to definition):

``` C#
    [Flags]
    public enum DisplayOrientation
    {
        Default = 0,
        LandscapeLeft = 1,
        LandscapeRight = 2,
        Portrait = 4,
    }
```

I have spent plenty of time working with iOS orientations (implementing iOS 6 orientation model for example). FaceDown and FaceUp are never used. As for PortraitUpsideDown I would recommend renaming it to PortraitDown (see http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-US/library/windowsphone/develop/microsoft.phone.controls.pageorientation%28v=vs.105%29.aspx).
## My recommendation

``` C#
    [Flags]
    public enum DisplayOrientation
    {
        Default = 0,
        LandscapeLeft = 1,
        LandscapeRight = 2,
        Portrait = 4,
        PortraitDown = 8,
        Unknown = 16
    }
```

Default can mean LandscapeLeft | LandscapeRight or Portrait depending on the requested resolution (the comment in MonoGame is wrong), so it should stay 0.

What do you guys think? Any input is welcome.

Further reading:
http://blogs.msdn.com/b/shawnhar/archive/2010/07/12/orientation-and-rotation-on-windows-phone.aspx

data.title: Detach from MonoSpider
data.body:
It is confusing and kinda crappy that mono/MonoGame is forked from monospider/monogame.

monospider/monogame was one of the two repos (the other was kangaroo/monogame) used in the transition of MonoGame from Codeplex to being hosted here on GitHub.

If we can have the owner of that repo delete it then MonoGame will become the new root of that network.  This is safe and MonoGame will retain the stars/forks/watchers that it has developed over the 2 years since it was forked from monospider.

The problem is no one knows who monospider is and the account looks abandoned with no activity in a year.

data.title: First working SpriteFontDescription .xnb written
data.body:
This pull request includes a couple of things.

First, SpriteFontDescription is working! 
![FontComparison](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/1228707/140685/dd91274e-7229-11e2-9f2d-f29ec0d43888.png)

At the moment it only outputs the texture in an uncompressed format. I left it this way for now because I was unsure of how we'd select the compression  for the font. Will it be via a property similar to how the Texture2DProcessor works? Either way, since Compression is already implemented, this is a rather quick fix.

At the moment, using generics in the pipeline was not working. Long story short, we are doing a dictionary lookup for readers and writers, but at runtime we can't use this lookup against an instance of this generic type. As far as the dictionary lookup is concerned, List<T> and List<Rectangle> aren't the same thing. I came up with a solution, but am unsure if it's the best one.

There are still some improvements to implement, but this is a good starting point.

data.title: [WP8] RenderTarget2D.GetData<Color> doesn't work
data.body: Always returns transparent pixels.

data.title: [WP8] RenderTargets do not work
data.body:
On Windows Phone 8, RenderTargets do not work properly, as it is (almost) always drawn on the screen with the color used in GraphicsDevice.Clear.
We have noticed that one of our rendertargets render correctly for about 25 frames, so not everything is lost. It seems that something is applied about half second after the game is running that stops RenderTargets from working. This means that we render one of our rendertargets once every update call and draw it in every draw call, but only render it up to 25 times.

Note: This has been mentioned quite a lot, but it seems that there is no open issue for it.

data.title: GL Shader Default Parameters
data.body:
When shaders are used in DX the EffectParameters have the correct default value based on what was set in the HLSL.

When shaders are converted to work in GL they do not have the correct default parameter values.  This is because MojoShader has no access to the default content of the constant buffers.

There are two solutions here.
1. Finally ditch MojoShader.
2. Reflect the HLSL version of the shader.

The first option would still require us to parse the value from the GLSL source as the GLSL code isn't really executed until runtime.

I tried the second option once, but it failed because DirectX11's shader reflection code cannot reflect SM3.x and below shaders.  I would have to build the shader twice or parse the default values from the textual HLSL code.

There are no easy solutions here unfortunately.

data.title: MGFX Integer And Boolean Types
data.body:
This commit fixes #1222.

I've added support for boolean and integer types in the Effect/Shader runtime.

In this process I optimized away the garbage generation in ConstantBuffer.SetData() by making EffectParameter always use an array type... even for singular values.  We also now do all type casting in EffectParameter.SetValue() instead of ConstantBuffer.SetData().
- EffectParameter now stores all values in Array types.
- ConstantBuffer.SetData() now assumes all parameters are Array types.
- Implemented SetValue/GetValue for boolean types in EffectParameter.
- Added exceptions when setting/getting the wrong type in EffectParameter.
- Removed EffectParameter.SetValue(object).

This changed several of the methods in EffectParameter.  I tested it on Windows OpenGL, Windows DirectX, and Windows Store apps.

It could use testing on iOS and Android as well as any MonoGame projects that make a big use of custom shaders.

data.title: Replaced NSTimer with CADisplayLink.
data.body:
This PR implements part of the discussion that started in https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/pull/1030 but severely got off topic.

Apple's documentation states that an NSTimer's effective resolution is limited to 50-100ms. Using a CADisplayLink is a preferred way to implement a high resolution timer, as we can see resolutions as fast as ~16-17ms.

Depending on the project there may or may not be a performance gain from this.

data.title: [FeatureRequest] BlackBerry 10 Support
data.body: Should a BlackBerry 10 support maybe be added?

data.title: RenderTarget2D size limited by screen size
data.body: In XNA a RenderTarget2D can be larger than the dimensions of the screen. I've used this ability a lot in my Windows code. On Mac though MonoGame seems to limit the size to the size of the screen. Admittedly this may not affect most users but it is a difference between the two platforms. (Issue may also exist on iOS and Android just don't have the resources to test)

data.title: Updated API docs for Storage/ classes.
Updated Readme.MD as requested in #1143.
data.body: I'm not sure if this is what you guys looking for but I've checked some bigger projects Readme.MD's and used a similar scheme as @tomspilman asked in #1143

data.title: No way to get application arguments
data.body: I've looked all over and it appears there are no way to get the arguments passed to the program. I found LaunchParameters but it was empty.
